question_user: Is a telecom provider treated as the sender of an automated spam if it only carried the traffic?
question_variants: Are telcos considered to have sent messages they merely transmit?
Does a network provider count as authorising an applicable message it only enables?
gold_answer_short: No. A provider that merely enables the sending is presumed not to have sent, caused, or authorised it, unless proven otherwise.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.48A(4), a telecommunications service provider that only provides the service enabling an applicable message to be sent is presumed not to have sent, caused to be sent, or authorised the message, unless the contrary is proved.

question_user: If my Wi-Fi was hijacked and messages were sent without my knowledge, am I responsible?
question_variants: Am I liable for messages sent from my router by an unknown person?
Do owners authorise messages sent through a compromised device?
gold_answer_short: Responsibility turns on knowledge and proof. Owners are presumed not to have sent or authorised messages sent without their knowledge, unless the contrary is proved.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48A(5) presumes an owner or authorised user did not send, cause to be sent, or authorise an applicable message if the device/service/network was controlled by another without their knowledge, unless proven otherwise.
ask_for_clarification_suggestions: Do you have any evidence that you knew about or consented to the sending at the time?

question_user: What counts as “control” over a device or network in this context?
question_variants: How does the PDPA define control for sending messages?
What forms of control qualify under the Act?
gold_answer_short: Control includes physical control or control through software or other means.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48A(6) states that “control” means either physical control or control via software or other means over the device, service, or network from which a message was sent.

question_user: Is sending messages to numbers generated by software or harvested from the internet allowed?
question_variants: Can I use address-harvesting tools or number generators to send messages?
Are messages to auto-generated or scraped numbers permitted?
gold_answer_short: No. Sending, causing, or authorising such applicable messages is prohibited.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48B(1) prohibits sending, causing to be sent, or authorising the sending of an applicable message (e.g., to numbers from dictionary attacks or address-harvesting software), subject to stated exceptions.

question_user: Are employees personally liable for sending such messages when acting in good faith on the job?
question_variants: Does an employee have a defence if they followed employer instructions?
Is there protection for staff who sent messages during their duties?
gold_answer_short: They may be exempt if they acted in good faith in the course of employment or under employer instructions.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.48B(2), the prohibition in s.48B(1) does not apply to an employee who, in good faith, sends/causes/authorises applicable messages in the course of employment or per employer instructions.

question_user: When would senior staff still be liable despite the employee exception?
question_variants: When does the carve-out not protect an employee who is an officer or partner?
Can officers or partners rely on the employee defence?
gold_answer_short: If they were an officer or partner who knew or ought to have known the number was an applicable number and the sending involved their consent, connivance, or neglect.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48B(3) removes the s.48B(2) protection where, at the time of sending, the person was an officer or partner who knew or ought reasonably to have known the number was an applicable telephone number, and the sending involved their consent/connivance or was due to their neglect.

question_user: Our vendor scraped numbers and auto-generated others, then messaged them for our campaign. Are we in breach?
question_variants: Are we liable if a vendor uses address harvesting and dictionary attacks?
Does using a third-party that scrapes numbers violate the PDPA?
gold_answer_short: It depends. Using harvested or generated numbers is generally prohibited; liability may turn on roles and any officer/partner involvement or employee good-faith exceptions.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48B(1) bans such sending. Employee good-faith protection exists (s.48B(2)), but officers/partners with knowledge or neglect are not protected (s.48B(3)). Responsibility depends on facts about authorisation and roles.
ask_for_clarification_suggestions: Was any officer or partner aware of the vendor’s methods or did they approve or neglect to prevent their use?

question_user: Where do the meanings of “officer” and “partner” come from for these offences?
question_variants: How are officer and partner defined for the PDPA’s message offences?
Which sections define officer/partner here?
gold_answer_short: They follow the definitions in sections 52(7) and 52A(7) of the Act.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48B(4) states that “corporation” and “officer” take their meaning from s.52(7), and “partner” from s.52A(7) (for partnerships and certain associations).

question_user: Does “disclose” personal data include giving someone access to it?
question_variants: Is providing access considered disclosure?
Does disclosure cover access rights?
gold_answer_short: Yes. Disclosure includes providing access to personal data.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48C(1) provides that “disclose”, in relation to personal data, includes providing access to personal data.

question_user: What does “harm” to an individual include under this Part?
question_variants: How is harm defined here?
Does harm cover non-physical effects?
gold_answer_short: Harm includes physical harm and harassment, alarm, or distress to the individual.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.48C(1), “harm”, in relation to an individual, includes any physical harm and harassment, alarm, or distress caused to the individual.

question_user: Are certain public officials excluded from these personal-data offences?
question_variants: Do relevant public officials fall outside this Part?
Who is excluded from offences like unauthorised disclosure?
gold_answer_short: Yes. This Part does not apply to specified public officials, including relevant public officials in Singapore public sector agencies and certain MAS directors, officers, or employees, for specified duties.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48C(2) states this Part does not apply to (a) a relevant public official in a Singapore public sector agency at the time of the offence, and (b) MAS directors/officers/employees for disclosure, use, or re-identification of information acquired in their duties/functions.

question_user: What are the elements and penalties for unauthorised disclosure of personal data by an individual?
question_variants: When is an individual guilty of unauthorised disclosure?
What must be proven for the disclosure offence and what is the penalty?
gold_answer_short: An individual commits an offence by unauthorised disclosure knowing it is unauthorised or being reckless about it; penalty is up to a $5,000 fine or 2 years’ imprisonment, or both.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48D(1) requires (a) disclosure or causing disclosure of personal data in an organisation’s/public agency’s possession/control, (b) without its authorisation, and (c) with knowledge of unauthorised status or recklessness. Penalty: fine up to $5,000 or imprisonment up to 2 years, or both.

question_user: What defences are available to someone charged with unauthorised disclosure?
question_variants: How can an accused defend against a s.48D(1) charge?
Are there statutory defences to disclosure offences?
gold_answer_short: Defences include the data being publicly available (with limits) or disclosure permitted/required by law, court order, reasonable belief of legal right, or other prescribed circumstances.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.48D(2), defences include: the data was publicly available (and the accused was not reckless about any contravention causing that), disclosure permitted/required by another law, ordered by a court, reasonable belief of legal right, or other prescribed circumstances.

question_user: Does this PDPA defence section override stricter limits on disclosure in other laws?
question_variants: Do other laws’ confidentiality rules still apply?
Does s.48D(2) affect obligations under other legislation?
gold_answer_short: Other laws still apply. The defence provision does not affect obligations, limits, or prohibitions under other written law.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48D(3) clarifies that s.48D(2) does not affect any obligation, limitation, or prohibition on disclosure under other written law or other law.

question_user: What does “gain” encompass in this Part’s definitions?
question_variants: How is gain defined here?
Does gain include opportunities, not just money?
gold_answer_short: Gain includes property or services (temporary or permanent) and opportunities to earn remuneration or financial advantage beyond remuneration.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.48C(1) defines “gain” as (a) a gain in property or a supply of services, whether temporary or permanent; or (b) an opportunity to earn remuneration or greater remuneration, or to gain a financial advantage otherwise than by way of remuneration.
